**Theodor Seuss Geisel** ([/ˈsuːs ˈɡaɪzəl/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English") ([![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:En-us-Geisel.ogg "About this sound")
[listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/97/En-us-Geisel.ogg "En-
us-Geisel.ogg"));[1] March 2, 1904 – September 24, 1991)[2] was an American
author, political cartoonist, poet, animator, book publisher, and artist, best
known for authoring [more than 60](/wiki/Dr._Seuss_bibliography "Dr. Seuss
bibliography") [children's books](/wiki/Children%27s_literature "Children's
literature") under the [pen name](/wiki/Pen_name "Pen name") **Doctor Seuss**
(abbreviated **Dr. Seuss**) ([/suːs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English")).[1] His work includes several of the most popular
children's books of all time, selling over 600 million copies and being
translated into more than 20 languages by the time of his death.[3]

Geisel adopted the name "Dr. Seuss" as an undergraduate at [Dartmouth
College](/wiki/Dartmouth_College "Dartmouth College") and a graduate student
at the [University of Oxford](/wiki/University_of_Oxford "University of
Oxford"). He left Oxford in 1927 to begin his career as an illustrator and
cartoonist for _[Vanity Fair](/wiki/Vanity_Fair_\(magazine\) "Vanity Fair
\(magazine\)")_ , _[Life](/wiki/Life_\(magazine\) "Life \(magazine\)")_ , and
various other publications. He also worked as an illustrator for [advertising
campaigns](/wiki/Advertising_campaign "Advertising campaign"), most notably
for [FLIT](/wiki/FLIT "FLIT") and [Standard Oil](/wiki/Standard_Oil "Standard
Oil"), and as a [political cartoonist](/wiki/Editorial_cartoon "Editorial
cartoon") for the New York newspaper _[PM](/wiki/PM_\(newspaper\) "PM
\(newspaper\)")_. He published his first children's book _[And to Think That I
Saw It on Mulberry Street](/wiki/And_to_Think_That_I_Saw_It_on_Mulberry_Street
"And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street")_ in 1937. During [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), he took a brief hiatus from children's
literature and worked in an animation department of the [United States
Army](/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army") where he produced several
short films, including _[Design for Death](/wiki/Design_for_Death "Design for
Death")_ , which later won the 1947 [Academy Award for Best Documentary
Feature](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Documentary_Feature "Academy Award for
Best Documentary Feature").[4]

After the war, Geisel focused on children's books once again, writing classics
like _[If I Ran the Zoo](/wiki/If_I_Ran_the_Zoo "If I Ran the Zoo")_ (1950),
_[Horton Hears a Who!](/wiki/Horton_Hears_a_Who! "Horton Hears a Who!")_
(1955), _[If I Ran the Circus](/wiki/If_I_Ran_the_Circus "If I Ran the
Circus")_ (1956), _[The Cat in the Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat "The Cat in
the Hat")_ (1957), _[How the Grinch Stole
Christmas!](/wiki/How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas! "How the Grinch Stole
Christmas!")_ (1957), and _[Green Eggs and Ham](/wiki/Green_Eggs_and_Ham
"Green Eggs and Ham")_ (1960). He published over 60 books during his career,
which have spawned numerous [adaptations](/wiki/Film_adaptation "Film
adaptation"), including 11 television specials, four feature films, [a
Broadway musical](/wiki/Seussical "Seussical"), and four television series.

Geisel won the [Lewis Carroll Shelf Award](/wiki/Lewis_Carroll_Shelf_Award
"Lewis Carroll Shelf Award") in 1958 for _Horton Hatches the Egg_ and again in
1961 for _And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street_. Geisel's birthday,
March 2, has been adopted as the annual date for [National Read Across America
Day](/wiki/Read_Across_America "Read Across America"), an initiative on
reading created by the [National Education
Association](/wiki/National_Education_Association "National Education
Association").

## Life and career

### Early years

Geisel was born and raised in [Springfield,
Massachusetts](/wiki/Springfield,_Massachusetts "Springfield, Massachusetts"),
the son of Henrietta (_née_ Seuss) and Theodor Robert Geisel.[5][6] [7] His
father managed the family brewery and was later appointed to supervise
Springfield's public park system by Mayor [John A.
Denison](/wiki/John_A._Denison "John A. Denison")[8] after the brewery closed
because of [Prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States "Prohibition
in the United States").[9] [Mulberry
Street](/wiki/Mulberry_Street_\(Springfield,_Massachusetts\) "Mulberry Street
\(Springfield, Massachusetts\)") in Springfield, made famous in Dr. Seuss'
first children's book _[And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry
Street](/wiki/And_to_Think_That_I_Saw_It_on_Mulberry_Street "And to Think That
I Saw It on Mulberry Street")_ , is less than a mile southwest of his boyhood
home on Fairfield Street. Geisel was raised a [Lutheran](/wiki/V "V").[10] He
enrolled at [Springfield Central High
School](/wiki/Springfield_Central_High_School "Springfield Central High
School") in 1917 and graduated in 1921. He took an art class as a freshman and
later became manager of the school soccer team.[11]

Geisel attended [Dartmouth College](/wiki/Dartmouth_College "Dartmouth
College"), graduating in 1925.[12] At Dartmouth, he joined the [Sigma Phi
Epsilon](/wiki/Sigma_Phi_Epsilon "Sigma Phi Epsilon") fraternity[5] and the
humor magazine _[Dartmouth Jack-O-Lantern](/wiki/Dartmouth_Jack-O-Lantern
"Dartmouth Jack-O-Lantern")_ , eventually rising to the rank of editor-in-
chief.[5] While at Dartmouth, he was caught drinking [gin](/wiki/Gin "Gin")
with nine friends in his room.[13] At the time, the possession and consumption
of alcohol was illegal under Prohibition laws, which remained in place between
1920 and 1933. As a result of this infraction, Dean [Craven
Laycock](/wiki/Craven_Laycock "Craven Laycock") insisted that Geisel resign
from all extracurricular activities, including the college humor magazine.[14]
To continue work on the _Jack-O-Lantern_ without the administration's
knowledge, Geisel began signing his work with the [pen name](/wiki/Pen_name
"Pen name") "Seuss". He was encouraged in his writing by professor of rhetoric
W. Benfield Pressey, whom he described as his "big inspiration for writing" at
Dartmouth.[15]

Upon graduating from Dartmouth, he entered [Lincoln College,
Oxford](/wiki/Lincoln_College,_Oxford "Lincoln College, Oxford"), intending to
earn a PhD in English literature.[16] At Oxford, he met [Helen
Palmer](/wiki/Helen_Palmer_\(author\) "Helen Palmer \(author\)"), who
encouraged him to give up becoming an English teacher in favor of pursuing
drawing as a career.[16]

### Early career

Geisel left Oxford without earning a degree and returned to the United States
in February 1927,[17] where he immediately began submitting writings and
drawings to magazines, book publishers, and advertising agencies.[18] Making
use of his time in Europe, he pitched a series of cartoons called _Eminent
Europeans_ to _[Life](/wiki/Life_\(magazine\) "Life \(magazine\)")_ magazine,
but the magazine passed on it. His first nationally published cartoon appeared
in the July 16, 1927, issue of _[The Saturday Evening
Post](/wiki/The_Saturday_Evening_Post "The Saturday Evening Post")_.[19] This
single $25 sale encouraged Geisel to move from Springfield to New York City.

Later that year, Geisel accepted a job as writer and illustrator at the humor
magazine _[Judge](/wiki/Judge_\(magazine\) "Judge \(magazine\)")_ , and he
felt financially stable enough to marry Helen.[20] His first cartoon for
_Judge_ appeared on October 22, 1927, and the Geisels were married on November
29. Geisel's first work signed "Dr. Seuss" was published in _Judge_ about six
months after he started working there.[21]

In early 1928, one of Geisel's cartoons for _Judge_ mentioned
[FLIT](/wiki/FLIT "FLIT"), a common bug spray at the time manufactured by
[Standard Oil of New Jersey](/wiki/Esso "Esso").[22] According to Geisel, the
wife of an advertising executive in charge of advertising FLIT saw Geisel's
cartoon at a hairdresser's and urged her husband to sign him.[23] Geisel's
first Flit ad appeared on May 31, 1928, and the campaign continued
sporadically until 1941.[24] The campaign's catchphrase "Quick, Henry, the
Flit!" became a part of popular culture. It spawned a song and was used as a
punch line for comedians such as [Fred Allen](/wiki/Fred_Allen "Fred Allen")
and [Jack Benny](/wiki/Jack_Benny "Jack Benny"). As Geisel gained notoriety
for the FLIT campaign, his work was in demand and began to appear regularly in
magazines such as _[Life](/wiki/Life_\(magazine\) "Life \(magazine\)")_ ,
_[Liberty](/wiki/Liberty_\(general_interest_magazine\) "Liberty \(general
interest magazine\)")_ , and _[Vanity Fair](/wiki/Vanity_Fair_\(magazine\)
"Vanity Fair \(magazine\)")_.

Geisel supported himself and his wife through the [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_States "Great Depression in
the United States") by drawing advertising for [General
Electric](/wiki/General_Electric "General Electric"), [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC"),
[Standard Oil](/wiki/Standard_Oil "Standard Oil"), [Narragansett Brewing
Company](/wiki/Narragansett_Brewing_Company "Narragansett Brewing Company"),
and many other companies. In 1935, he wrote and drew a short-lived comic strip
called _[Hejji](/wiki/Hejji "Hejji")_.[25]

The increased income allowed the Geisels to move to better quarters and to
socialize in higher social circles.[26] They became friends with the wealthy
family of banker [Frank A. Vanderlip](/wiki/Frank_A._Vanderlip "Frank A.
Vanderlip"). They also traveled extensively: by 1936, Geisel and his wife had
visited 30 countries together. They did not have children, neither kept
regular office hours, and they had ample money.[27] Geisel also felt that the
traveling helped his creativity.

In 1936, the couple were returning from an ocean voyage to Europe when the
rhythm of the ship's engines inspired the poem that became his first book:
_[And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry
Street](/wiki/And_to_Think_That_I_Saw_It_on_Mulberry_Street "And to Think That
I Saw It on Mulberry Street")_.[28] Based on Geisel's varied accounts, the
book was rejected by between 20 and 43 publishers.[29][30] According to
Geisel, he was walking home to burn the manuscript when a chance encounter
with an old Dartmouth classmate led to its publication by [Vanguard
Press](/wiki/Vanguard_Press "Vanguard Press").[31] Geisel wrote four more
books before the US entered World War II. This included _[The 500 Hats of
Bartholomew Cubbins](/wiki/The_500_Hats_of_Bartholomew_Cubbins "The 500 Hats
of Bartholomew Cubbins")_ in 1938, as well as _[The King's
Stilts](/wiki/The_King%27s_Stilts "The King's Stilts")_ and _[The Seven Lady
Godivas](/wiki/The_Seven_Lady_Godivas "The Seven Lady Godivas")_ in 1939, all
of which were in prose, atypically for him. This was followed by _[Horton
Hatches the Egg](/wiki/Horton_Hatches_the_Egg "Horton Hatches the Egg")_ in
1940, in which Geisel returned to the use of poetry.

### Essomarine

Geisel gained a significant public profile through a program for motor boat
lubricants produced by Standard Oil under the brand name Essomarine.[32] He
later recounted that [Harry Bruno](/wiki/Harry_Bruno "Harry Bruno"), Ted Cook,
and Verne Carrier worked with him at the National Motor Boat Show on exhibits
referred to as the Seuss Navy.[33]

In 1934, Geisel produced a 30-page booklet titled _Secrets of the Deep_ which
was available by mail after June. At the January [boat show](/wiki/Boat_show
"Boat show") for 1935, visitors filled out order cards to receive _Secrets_.
Geisel drew up a Certificate of Commission for visitors in 1936. A mock ship
deck called _SS Essomarine_ provided the scene where photos of "Admirals" were
taken. That summer, Geisel released a second volume of _Secrets_. For the 1937
show, he sculpted Marine Muggs and designed a flag for the Seuss
Navy.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

The following year featured "Little Dramas of the Deep", a six-act play with
ten characters. According to Geisel's sister, "He plans the whole show with
scenery and action and then, standing in a realistic
[bridge](/wiki/Bridge_\(nautical\) "Bridge \(nautical\)"), reels off a speech
which combines advertising with humor." For 1939, exhibitors made available
the Nuzzlepuss [ashtray](/wiki/Ashtray "Ashtray") and illustrated tide-table
calendars.

A Seuss Navy Luncheon was held on January 11, 1940, at the [Waldorf-Astoria
Hotel](/wiki/Waldorf_Astoria_New_York "Waldorf Astoria New York"). At that
year's boat show, Geisel provided the Navigamarama exhibit and the _Sea
Lawyers Gazette_.

The final contribution to the Essomarine project was the
[mermaid](/wiki/Mermaid "Mermaid") Essie Neptune and her pet whale in 1941.
The exhibit offered photos for a Happy Cruising passport.[34]

### World War II-era work

![File:The
Goldbrick.ogv](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/The_Goldbrick.ogv/220px
--The_Goldbrick.ogv.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d5/The_Goldbrick.ogv "Play
media")

[](/wiki/File:The_Goldbrick.ogv "Enlarge")

"The Goldbrick", Private Snafu episode written by Geisel, 1943

As World War II began, Geisel turned to political cartoons, drawing over 400
in two years as editorial cartoonist for the left-leaning New York City daily
newspaper, _[PM](/wiki/PM_\(newspaper\) "PM \(newspaper\)")_.[35] Geisel's
political cartoons, later published in _[Dr. Seuss Goes to
War](/wiki/Dr._Seuss_Goes_to_War "Dr. Seuss Goes to War")_ , denounced
[Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") and
[Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini") and were highly
critical of non-interventionists ("isolationists"), most notably [Charles
Lindbergh](/wiki/Charles_Lindbergh "Charles Lindbergh"), who opposed US entry
into the war.[36] One cartoon[37] depicted all [Japanese
Americans](/wiki/Japanese_Americans "Japanese Americans") as latent traitors
or [fifth-columnists](/wiki/Fifth_column "Fifth column"), while other cartoons
simultaneously deplored the racism at home against [Jews](/wiki/Jews "Jews")
and blacks that harmed the war effort.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] His
cartoons were strongly supportive of [President
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt")'s handling of
the war, combining the usual exhortations to ration and contribute to the war
effort with frequent attacks on Congress[38] (especially the [Republican
Party](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party \(United
States\)")),[39] parts of the press (such as the _[New York Daily
News](/wiki/New_York_Daily_News "New York Daily News")_ , _[Chicago
Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Tribune "Chicago Tribune")_ , and _[Washington Times-
Herald](/wiki/Washington_Times-Herald "Washington Times-Herald")_),[40] and
others for criticism of Roosevelt, criticism of aid to the Soviet
Union,[41][42] investigation of suspected Communists,[43] and other offences
that he depicted as leading to disunity and helping the Nazis, intentionally
or inadvertently.

In 1942, Geisel turned his energies to direct support of the U.S. war effort.
First, he worked drawing posters for the [Treasury
Department](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Treasury "United States
Department of the Treasury") and the [War Production
Board](/wiki/War_Production_Board "War Production Board"). Then, in 1943, he
joined the Army as a [Captain](/wiki/Captain_\(United_States_O-3\) "Captain
\(United States O-3\)") and was commander of the Animation Department of the
[First Motion Picture Unit](/wiki/First_Motion_Picture_Unit "First Motion
Picture Unit") of the [United States Army Air
Forces](/wiki/United_States_Army_Air_Forces "United States Army Air Forces"),
where he wrote films that included _[Your Job in
Germany](/wiki/Your_Job_in_Germany "Your Job in Germany")_ , a 1945 propaganda
film about peace in Europe after World War II; _[Our Job in
Japan](/wiki/Our_Job_in_Japan "Our Job in Japan")_ ; and the _[Private
Snafu](/wiki/Private_Snafu "Private Snafu")_ series of adult army training
films. While in the Army, he was awarded the [Legion of
Merit](/wiki/Legion_of_Merit "Legion of Merit").[44] _Our Job in Japan_ became
the basis for the commercially released film _[Design for
Death](/wiki/Design_for_Death "Design for Death")_ (1947), a study of
[Japanese culture](/wiki/Culture_of_Japan "Culture of Japan") that won the
[Academy Award for Best Documentary
Feature](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Documentary_Feature "Academy Award for
Best Documentary Feature").[45] _[Gerald McBoing-Boing](/wiki/Gerald_McBoing-
Boing "Gerald McBoing-Boing")_ (1950) was based on an original story by Seuss
and won the [Academy Award for Best Animated Short
Film](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Short_Film#1950s "Academy Award
for Best Animated Short Film").[46]

### Later years

After the war, Geisel and his wife moved to [La Jolla,
California](/wiki/La_Jolla,_San_Diego,_California "La Jolla, San Diego,
California") where he returned to writing children's books. He wrote many,
including such favorites as _[If I Ran the Zoo](/wiki/If_I_Ran_the_Zoo "If I
Ran the Zoo")_ (1950), _[Horton Hears a Who!](/wiki/Horton_Hears_a_Who!
"Horton Hears a Who!")_ (1955), _[If I Ran the
Circus](/wiki/If_I_Ran_the_Circus "If I Ran the Circus")_ (1956), _[The Cat in
the Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat "The Cat in the Hat")_ (1957), _[How the
Grinch Stole Christmas!](/wiki/How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas! "How the Grinch
Stole Christmas!")_ (1957), and _[Green Eggs and Ham](/wiki/Green_Eggs_and_Ham
"Green Eggs and Ham")_ (1960). He received numerous awards throughout his
career, but he won neither the [Caldecott Medal](/wiki/Caldecott_Medal
"Caldecott Medal") nor the [Newbery Medal](/wiki/Newbery_Medal "Newbery
Medal"). Three of his titles from this period were, however, chosen as
Caldecott runners-up (now referred to as Caldecott Honor books): _[McElligot's
Pool](/wiki/McElligot%27s_Pool "McElligot's Pool")_ (1947), _Bartholomew and
the Oobleck_ (1949), and _If I Ran the Zoo_ (1950). Dr Seuss also wrote the
[musical](/wiki/Musical_film "Musical film") and [fantasy
film](/wiki/Fantasy_film "Fantasy film") _[The 5,000 Fingers of Dr.
T.](/wiki/The_5,000_Fingers_of_Dr._T. "The 5,000 Fingers of Dr. T.")_ , which
was released in 1953. The movie was a critical and financial failure, and
Geisel never attempted another feature film. During the 1950s, he also
published a number of illustrated short stories, mostly in
_[Redbook](/wiki/Redbook "Redbook")_ Magazine. Some of these were later
collected (in volumes such as _The Sneetches and Other Stories_) or reworked
into independent books (_If I Ran the Zoo_). A number have never been
reprinted since their original appearances.

In May 1954, _[Life](/wiki/Life_\(magazine\) "Life \(magazine\)")_ magazine
published a report on [illiteracy](/wiki/Literacy "Literacy") among school
children which concluded that children were not learning to read because their
books were boring. William Ellsworth Spaulding was the director of the
education division at Houghton Mifflin (he later became its chairman), and he
compiled a list of 348 words that he felt were important for first-graders to
recognize. He asked Geisel to cut the list to 250 words and to write a book
using only those words.[47] Spaulding challenged Geisel to "bring back a book
children can't put down".[48] Nine months later, Geisel completed _[The Cat in
the Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat "The Cat in the Hat")_ , using 236 of the
words given to him. It retained the drawing style, verse rhythms, and all the
imaginative power of Geisel's earlier works but, because of its simplified
vocabulary, it could be read by beginning readers. _The Cat in the Hat_ and
subsequent books written for young children achieved significant international
success and they remain very popular today. In 2009, _Green Eggs and Ham_ sold
540,366 copies, _The Cat in the Hat_ sold 452,258 copies, and _[One Fish, Two
Fish, Red Fish, Blue Fish](/wiki/One_Fish,_Two_Fish,_Red_Fish,_Blue_Fish "One
Fish, Two Fish, Red Fish, Blue Fish")_ (1960) sold 409,068 copies—outselling
the majority of newly published children's books.[49]

Geisel went on to write many other children's books, both in his new
simplified-vocabulary manner (sold as [Beginner Books](/wiki/Beginner_Books
"Beginner Books")) and in his older, more elaborate style.

In 1956, Dartmouth awarded Geisel with an honorary doctorate, finally
justifying the "Dr." in his pen name.

On April 28, 1958, Geisel appeared on an episode of the panel game show _[To
Tell the Truth](/wiki/To_Tell_the_Truth "To Tell the Truth")_.[50]

Geisel's wife Helen had a long struggle with illnesses, including cancer and
emotional pain over Geisel's affair with Audrey Stone Dimond. On October 23,
1967, Helen committed [suicide](/wiki/Suicide "Suicide"); Geisel married
Dimond on June 21, 1968.[51] Though he devoted most of his life to writing
children's books, Geisel had no children of his own, saying of children: "You
have 'em; I'll entertain 'em."[51] Dimond added that Geisel "lived his whole
life without children and he was very happy without children."[51]

Geisel received the [Laura Ingalls Wilder
Medal](/wiki/Laura_Ingalls_Wilder_Medal "Laura Ingalls Wilder Medal") from the
[professional children's
librarians](/wiki/Association_for_Library_Service_to_Children "Association for
Library Service to Children") in 1980, recognizing his "substantial and
lasting contributions to children's literature". At the time, it was awarded
every five years.[52] He won a [special Pulitzer
Prize](/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize_Special_Citations_and_Awards "Pulitzer Prize
Special Citations and Awards") in 1984 citing his "contribution over nearly
half a century to the education and enjoyment of America's children and their
parents".[53]

## Illness, death, and posthumous honors

Geisel died of [oral cancer](/wiki/Oral_cancer "Oral cancer") on September 24,
1991 at his home in La Jolla at the age of 87.[54][55] He was cremated and his
ashes were scattered. On December 1, 1995, four years after his death,
[University of California, San
Diego](/wiki/University_of_California,_San_Diego "University of California,
San Diego")'s University Library Building was renamed [Geisel
Library](/wiki/Geisel_Library "Geisel Library") in honor of Geisel and Audrey
for the generous contributions that they made to the library and their
devotion to improving literacy.[56]

While Geisel was living in La Jolla, the [United States Postal
Service](/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service "United States Postal Service")
and others frequently confused him with fellow La Jolla resident [Dr. Hans
Suess](/wiki/Hans_Suess "Hans Suess"). Their names have been linked together
posthumously: the personal papers of Hans Suess are housed in the Geisel
Library.[57]

In 2002, the [Dr. Seuss National Memorial Sculpture
Garden](/wiki/Dr._Seuss_Memorial "Dr. Seuss Memorial") opened in his
birthplace of [Springfield, Massachusetts](/wiki/Springfield,_Massachusetts
"Springfield, Massachusetts"), featuring sculptures of Geisel and of many of
his characters. On May 28, 2008, California Governor [Arnold
Schwarzenegger](/wiki/Arnold_Schwarzenegger "Arnold Schwarzenegger") and First
Lady [Maria Shriver](/wiki/Maria_Shriver "Maria Shriver") announced that
Geisel would be inducted into the [California Hall of
Fame](/wiki/California_Hall_of_Fame "California Hall of Fame") located at [The
California Museum for History, Women and the Arts](/wiki/The_California_Museum
"The California Museum"). The induction ceremony took place December 15 and
Geisel's widow Audrey accepted the honor in his place. On March 2, 2009, the
[Web search engine](/wiki/Web_search_engine "Web search engine")
[Google](/wiki/Google "Google") temporarily changed its
[logo](/wiki/Google_logo "Google logo") to commemorate Geisel's birthday (a
practice that it often follows for various holidays and events).[58]

In 2004, U.S. children's librarians established the annual [Theodor Seuss
Geisel Award](/wiki/Geisel_Award "Geisel Award") to recognize "the most
distinguished American book for beginning readers published in English in the
United States during the preceding year". It should "demonstrate creativity
and imagination to engage children in reading" from [pre-
kindergarten](/wiki/Pre-kindergarten "Pre-kindergarten") to [second
grade](/wiki/Second_grade "Second grade").[59]

At Geisel's alma mater of Dartmouth, more than 90 percent of incoming first-
year students participate in pre-registration [Dartmouth Outing
Club](/wiki/Dartmouth_Outing_Club "Dartmouth Outing Club") trips into the New
Hampshire wilderness. It is traditional for students returning from the trips
to stay overnight at Dartmouth's [Moosilauke Ravine
Lodge](/wiki/Moosilauke_Ravine_Lodge "Moosilauke Ravine Lodge"), where they
are served green eggs and ham for breakfast in honor of Dr. Seuss. On April 4,
2012, the Dartmouth Medical School was renamed the [Audrey and Theodor Geisel
School of Medicine](/wiki/Geisel_School_of_Medicine "Geisel School of
Medicine") in honor of their many years of generosity to the college.[60]

Dr. Seuss's honors include two [Academy Awards](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy
Awards"), two [Emmy Awards](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award"), a [Peabody
Award](/wiki/Peabody_Award "Peabody Award"), the [Laura Ingalls Wilder
Medal](/wiki/Laura_Ingalls_Wilder_Medal "Laura Ingalls Wilder Medal"), and the
[Pulitzer Prize](/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize "Pulitzer Prize").

Dr. Seuss has a star on the [Hollywood Walk of
Fame](/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame "Hollywood Walk of Fame") at the 6500 block
of [Hollywood Boulevard](/wiki/Hollywood_Boulevard "Hollywood Boulevard").[61]

## Pen names and pronunciations

Geisel's most famous pen name is regularly pronounced
[/suːs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"),[1] an
[anglicized](/wiki/Anglicisation "Anglicisation") pronunciation inconsistent
with his German surname (the standard German pronunciation is
[[ˈzɔʏ̯s]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Standard_German "Help:IPA/Standard German")). He
himself noted that it rhymed with "voice" (his own pronunciation being
[/sɔɪs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")). Alexander Laing, one of
his collaborators on the _[Dartmouth Jack-O-Lantern](/wiki/Dartmouth_Jack-O-
Lantern "Dartmouth Jack-O-Lantern")_ ,[62] wrote of it:

> You're wrong as the deuce  
>  And you shouldn't rejoice  
>  If you're calling him Seuss.  
>  He pronounces it Soice[63] (or Zoice)[64]

Geisel switched to the anglicized pronunciation because it "evoked a figure
advantageous for an author of children's books to be associated with—[Mother
Goose](/wiki/Mother_Goose "Mother Goose")"[48] and because most people used
this pronunciation. He added the "Doctor (abbreviated Dr.)" to his pen name
because his father had always wanted him to practice medicine.[65]

For books that Geisel wrote and others illustrated, he used the pen name "Theo
LeSieg", starting with _[I Wish That I Had Duck
Feet](/wiki/I_Wish_That_I_Had_Duck_Feet "I Wish That I Had Duck Feet")_
published in 1965. "LeSieg" is "Geisel" spelled backward.[66] Geisel also
published one book under the name Rosetta Stone, 1975's _Because a Little Bug
Went Ka-Choo!!_ , a collaboration with [Michael K.
Frith](/wiki/Michael_K._Frith "Michael K. Frith"). Frith and Geisel chose the
name in honor of Geisel's second wife Audrey, whose maiden name was Stone.[67]

## Political views

Main article: [Political messages of Dr.
Seuss](/wiki/Political_messages_of_Dr._Seuss "Political messages of Dr.
Seuss")

Geisel was a liberal [Democrat](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\)
"Democratic Party \(United States\)") and a supporter of President [Franklin
D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt") and the
[New Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal"). His early political cartoons show a
passionate opposition to fascism, and he urged action against it both before
and after the United States entered World War II. His cartoons portrayed the
fear of communism as overstated, finding greater threats in the [House Un-
American Activities Committee](/wiki/House_Un-American_Activities_Committee
"House Un-American Activities Committee") and those who threatened to cut the
United States' "life line"[42] to Stalin and the USSR, whom he once depicted
as a [porter](/wiki/Porter_\(carrier\) "Porter \(carrier\)") carrying "our war
load".[41]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Seuss_cartoon.png/220px-
Seuss_cartoon.png)](/wiki/File:Seuss_cartoon.png)

[](/wiki/File:Seuss_cartoon.png "Enlarge")

Dr. Seuss 1942 cartoon with the caption 'Waiting for the Signal from Home'

Geisel supported the [internment of Japanese
Americans](/wiki/Internment_of_Japanese_Americans "Internment of Japanese
Americans") during World War II. His treatment of the Japanese and of Japanese
Americans (between whom he often failed to differentiate) has struck many
readers as a [moral blind spot](/wiki/Moral_blindness "Moral blindness").[68]
On the issue of the Japanese, he is quoted as saying:

> But right now, when the Japs are planting their hatchets in our skulls, it
> seems like a hell of a time for us to smile and warble: "Brothers!" It is a
> rather flabby battle cry. If we want to win, we've got to kill Japs, whether
> it depresses [John Haynes Holmes](/wiki/John_Haynes_Holmes "John Haynes
> Holmes") or not. We can get palsy-walsy afterward with those that are
> left.[69]

After the war, though, Geisel overcame his feelings of animosity, using his
book _[Horton Hears a Who!](/wiki/Horton_Hears_a_Who! "Horton Hears a Who!")_
(1954) as an [allegory](/wiki/Allegory "Allegory") for the Hiroshima bombing
and the American post-war [occupation of Japan](/wiki/Occupation_of_Japan
"Occupation of Japan"), as well as dedicating the book to a Japanese
friend.[70]

In 1948, after living and working in Hollywood for years, Geisel moved to La
Jolla, California, a predominantly Republican town.[71]

Geisel converted a copy of one of his famous children's books, _[Marvin K.
Mooney Will You Please Go Now!](/wiki/Marvin_K._Mooney_Will_You_Please_Go_Now!
"Marvin K. Mooney Will You Please Go Now!")_ , into a [polemic](/wiki/Polemic
"Polemic") shortly before the end of the 1972–1974 [Watergate
scandal](/wiki/Watergate_scandal "Watergate scandal"), in which [United States
president](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States") [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") resigned, by
replacing the name of the main character everywhere that it occurred.[72]
"Richard M. Nixon, Will You Please Go Now!" was published in major newspapers
through the [column](/wiki/Column_\(periodical\) "Column \(periodical\)") of
his friend [Art Buchwald](/wiki/Art_Buchwald "Art Buchwald").[72]

The line "a person's a person, no matter _how_ small!!" from _Horton Hears a
Who!_ has been used widely as a slogan by the [pro-life](/wiki/Anti-
abortion_movements "Anti-abortion movements") movement in the U.S., despite
the objections of Geisel's widow. The line was first used in such a way in
1986; he demanded a retraction and received one.[73]

### In his books

Geisel made a point of not beginning to write his stories with a moral in
mind, stating that "kids can see a moral coming a mile off." He was not
against writing about issues, however; he said that "there's an inherent moral
in any story",[74] and he remarked that he was "subversive as hell."[75]

Many of Geisel's books express his views on a remarkable variety of social and
political issues: _[The Lorax](/wiki/The_Lorax "The Lorax")_ (1971), about
environmentalism and [anti-consumerism](/wiki/Anti-consumerism "Anti-
consumerism"); "[The Sneetches](/wiki/The_Sneetches_and_Other_Stories "The
Sneetches and Other Stories")" (1961), about [racial
equality](/wiki/Racial_equality "Racial equality"); _[The Butter Battle
Book](/wiki/The_Butter_Battle_Book "The Butter Battle Book")_ (1984), about
the [arms race](/wiki/Arms_race "Arms race"); _[Yertle the
Turtle](/wiki/Yertle_the_Turtle_and_Other_Stories "Yertle the Turtle and Other
Stories")_ (1958), about [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") and
[anti-authoritarianism](/wiki/Anti-authoritarianism "Anti-authoritarianism");
_[How the Grinch Stole Christmas!](/wiki/How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas! "How
the Grinch Stole Christmas!")_ (1957), criticizing the
[materialism](/wiki/Materialism "Materialism") and
[consumerism](/wiki/Consumerism "Consumerism") of the Christmas season; and
_[Horton Hears a Who!](/wiki/Horton_Hears_a_Who! "Horton Hears a Who!")_
(1954), about anti-[isolationism](/wiki/Isolationism "Isolationism") and
[internationalism](/wiki/Internationalism_\(politics\) "Internationalism
\(politics\)").[48][70]

## Poetic meters

Geisel wrote most of his books in [anapestic
tetrameter](/wiki/Anapestic_tetrameter "Anapestic tetrameter"), a [poetic
meter](/wiki/Meter_\(poetry\) "Meter \(poetry\)") employed by many poets of
the English literary canon. This is often suggested as one of the reasons that
Geisel's writing was so well received.[76][77]

Anapestic tetrameter consists of four rhythmic units called
[anapests](/wiki/Anapaest "Anapaest"), each composed of two weak syllables
followed by one strong syllable (the beat); often, the first weak syllable is
omitted, or an additional weak syllable is added at the end. An example of
this meter can be found in Geisel's "Yertle the Turtle", from _[Yertle the
Turtle and Other Stories](/wiki/Yertle_the_Turtle_and_Other_Stories "Yertle
the Turtle and Other Stories")_ :

> And to**day** the Great **Yer** tle, that **Mar** velous **he**  
>  Is **King** of the **Mud**. That is **all** he can **see**.[78]

Some books by Geisel that are written mainly in anapestic tetrameter also
contain many lines written in [amphibrachic tetrameter](/wiki/Amphibrach
"Amphibrach"), such as these from _If I Ran the Circus_ :

> All **rea** dy to **put** up the **tents** for my **cir** cus.  
>  I **think** I will **call** it the **Cir** cus Mc**Gur** kus.

> And **NOW** comes an **act** of E**nor** mous E**nor** mance!  
>  No **for** mer per**for** mer's per**formed** this per**for** mance!

Geisel also wrote verse in [trochaic tetrameter](/wiki/Trochaic_tetrameter
"Trochaic tetrameter"), an arrangement of a strong syllable followed by a weak
syllable, with four units per line (for example, the title of _[**One** Fish
**Two** Fish **Red** Fish **Blue**
Fish](/wiki/One_Fish,_Two_Fish,_Red_Fish,_Blue_Fish "One Fish, Two Fish, Red
Fish, Blue Fish")_). Traditionally, English trochaic meter permits the final
weak position in the line to be omitted, which allows both masculine and
feminine rhymes.

Geisel generally maintained trochaic meter for only brief passages, and for
longer stretches typically mixed it with [iambic
tetrameter](/wiki/Iambic_tetrameter "Iambic tetrameter"), which consists of a
weak syllable followed by a strong, and is generally considered easier to
write. Thus, for example, the magicians in _[Bartholomew and the
Oobleck](/wiki/Bartholomew_and_the_Oobleck "Bartholomew and the Oobleck")_
make their first appearance chanting in [trochees](/wiki/Trochee "Trochee")
(thus resembling the witches of [Shakespeare's](/wiki/William_Shakespeare
"William Shakespeare") _[Macbeth](/wiki/Macbeth "Macbeth")_):

> **Shuff** le, **duff** le, **muzz** le, **muff**

They then switch to [iambs](/wiki/Iamb_\(poetry\) "Iamb \(poetry\)") for the
oobleck spell:

> Go **make** the **Oob** leck **tum** ble **down**  
>  On **ev** ery **street** , in **ev** ery **town**![79]

Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(September 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Ted_Geisel_NYWTS.jpg/220px-
Ted_Geisel_NYWTS.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ted_Geisel_NYWTS.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ted_Geisel_NYWTS.jpg "Enlarge")

Geisel at work on a drawing of the [Grinch](/wiki/Grinch "Grinch") for _[How
the Grinch Stole Christmas!](/wiki/How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas! "How the
Grinch Stole Christmas!")_ in 1957

Geisel's early artwork often employed the shaded texture of pencil drawings or
[watercolors](/wiki/Watercolor "Watercolor"), but in his children's books of
the postwar period, he generally made use of a starker medium—pen and
ink—normally using just black, white, and one or two colors. His later books,
such as _[The Lorax](/wiki/The_Lorax "The Lorax"),_ used more colors.

Geisel's style was unique – his figures are often "rounded" and somewhat
droopy. This is true, for instance, of the faces of [the
Grinch](/wiki/The_grinch "The grinch") and [the Cat in the
Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat "The Cat in the Hat"). Almost all his buildings
and machinery were devoid of straight lines when they were drawn, even when he
was representing real objects. For example, _[If I Ran the
Circus](/wiki/If_I_Ran_the_Circus "If I Ran the Circus")_ shows a droopy
hoisting crane and a droopy [steam calliope](/wiki/Steam_calliope "Steam
calliope").

Geisel evidently enjoyed drawing architecturally elaborate objects. His
endlessly varied but never rectilinear palaces, ramps, platforms, and free-
standing stairways are among his most evocative creations. Geisel also drew
complex imaginary machines, such as the _Audio-Telly-O-Tally-O-Count_ , from
_[Dr. Seuss's Sleep Book](/wiki/Dr._Seuss%27s_Sleep_Book "Dr. Seuss's Sleep
Book")_, or the "most peculiar machine" of Sylvester McMonkey McBean in _[The
Sneetches](/wiki/The_Sneetches "The Sneetches")_. Geisel also liked drawing
outlandish arrangements of feathers or fur: for example, the 500th hat of
_[Bartholomew Cubbins](/wiki/Bartholomew_Cubbins "Bartholomew Cubbins")_ , the
tail of _[Gertrude McFuzz](/wiki/Gertrude_McFuzz "Gertrude McFuzz")_ , and the
pet for girls who like to brush and comb, in _One Fish, Two Fish, Red Fish,
Blue Fish_.

Geisel's illustrations often convey motion vividly. He was fond of a sort of
"voilà" gesture in which the hand flips outward and the fingers spread
slightly backward with the thumb up. This motion is done by Ish in _One Fish,
Two Fish, Red Fish, Blue Fish_ when he creates fish (who perform the gesture
with their fins), in the introduction of the various acts of _If I Ran the
Circus_ , and in the introduction of the "Little Cats" in _[The Cat in the Hat
Comes Back](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat "The Cat in the Hat")_. He was also fond
of drawing hands with interlocked fingers, making it look as though his
characters were twiddling their thumbs.

Geisel also follows the [cartoon](/wiki/Cartoon "Cartoon") tradition of
showing [motion with lines](/wiki/Motion_lines "Motion lines"), like in the
sweeping lines that accompany Sneelock's final dive in _If I Ran the Circus_.
Cartoon lines are also used to illustrate the action of the senses—sight,
smell, and hearing—in _The Big Brag,_ and lines even illustrate "thought", as
in the moment when the Grinch conceives his awful plan to ruin Christmas.

### Recurring images

Geisel's early work in advertising and [editorial
cartooning](/wiki/Editorial_cartoonist "Editorial cartoonist") helped him to
produce "sketches" of things that received more perfect realization later in
his children's books. Often, the expressive use to which Geisel put an image
later on was quite different from the original.[80] Here are some examples:

  * An editorial cartoon from July 16, 1941[81] depicts a whale resting on the top of a mountain as a [parody](/wiki/Parody "Parody") of American [isolationists](/wiki/Isolationism "Isolationism"), especially [Charles Lindbergh](/wiki/Charles_Lindbergh "Charles Lindbergh"). This was later rendered (with no apparent political content) as the Wumbus of _On Beyond Zebra_ (1955). Seussian whales (cheerful and balloon-shaped, with long eyelashes) also occur in _McElligot 's Pool_, _If I Ran the Circus_ , and other books.
  * Another editorial cartoon from 1941[82] shows a long cow with many legs and udders representing the conquered nations of Europe being milked by [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler"). This later became the Umbus of _On Beyond Zebra_.
  * The tower of turtles in a 1942 editorial cartoon[83] prefigures a similar tower in _[Yertle the Turtle](/wiki/Yertle_the_Turtle_and_Other_Stories "Yertle the Turtle and Other Stories")_. This theme also appeared in a _Judge_ cartoon as one letter of a hieroglyphic message, and in Geisel's short-lived comic strip _[Hejji](/wiki/Hejji "Hejji")_. Geisel once stated that Yertle the Turtle was Adolf Hitler.[84]
  * Little cats A, B, and C (as well as the rest of the alphabet) who spring from each other's hats appeared in a [Ford Motor Company ⋅](/w/index.php?title=Ford_Motor_Company_%E2%8B%85&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ford Motor Company ⋅ \(page does not exist\)") ad.
  * The connected beards in _Did I Ever Tell You How Lucky You Are?_ appear frequently in Geisel's work, most notably in _Hejji_ , which featured two goats joined at the beard, _The 5,000 Fingers of Dr. T._ , which featured two roller-skating guards joined at the beard, and a political cartoon in which [Nazism](/wiki/Nazism "Nazism") and the [America First movement](/wiki/America_First_Committee "America First Committee") are portrayed as "the men with the Siamese Beard".
  * Geisel's earliest elephants were for advertising and had somewhat wrinkly ears, much as real elephants do.[85] With _[And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street](/wiki/And_to_Think_That_I_Saw_It_on_Mulberry_Street "And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street")!_ (1937) and _[Horton Hatches the Egg](/wiki/Horton_Hatches_the_Egg "Horton Hatches the Egg")_ (1940), the ears became more stylized, somewhat like [angel](/wiki/Angel "Angel") wings and thus appropriate to the saintly Horton. During World War II, the elephant image appeared as an emblem for India in four editorial cartoons.[86] Horton and similar elephants appear frequently in the postwar children's books.
  * While drawing advertisements for [Flit](/wiki/FLIT "FLIT"), Geisel became adept at drawing insects with huge stingers,[87] shaped like a gentle S-curve and with a sharp end that included a rearward-pointing barb on its lower side. Their facial expressions depict gleeful malevolence. These insects were later rendered in an editorial cartoon as a swarm of Allied aircraft[88] (1942), and again as the Sneedle of _On Beyond Zebra_ , and yet again as the Skritz in _[I Had Trouble in Getting to Solla Sollew](/wiki/I_Had_Trouble_in_Getting_to_Solla_Sollew "I Had Trouble in Getting to Solla Sollew")_.
  * There are many examples of creatures who arrange themselves in repeating patterns, such as the "Two and fro walkers, who march in five layers", and the Through-Horns Jumping Deer in _[If I Ran the Circus](/wiki/If_I_Ran_the_Circus "If I Ran the Circus")_ , and the arrangement of birds which the protagonist of _[Oh, the Places You'll Go!](/wiki/Oh,_the_Places_You%27ll_Go! "Oh, the Places You'll Go!")_ walks through, as the narrator admonishes him to "... always be dexterous and deft, and never mix up your right foot with your left."

## Publications

Further information: [Dr. Seuss bibliography](/wiki/Dr._Seuss_bibliography
"Dr. Seuss bibliography")

Geisel wrote more than 60 books over the course of his long career. Most were
published under his well-known pseudonym Dr. Seuss, though he also authored
more than a dozen books as Theo LeSieg and one as Rosetta Stone. His books
have topped many bestseller lists, sold over 600 million copies, and been
translated into more than 20 languages.[3] In 2000, _Publishers Weekly_
compiled a list of the [best-selling children's
books](/wiki/Best_selling_books "Best selling books") of all time; of the top
100 hardcover books, 16 were written by Geisel, including _[Green Eggs and
Ham](/wiki/Green_Eggs_and_Ham "Green Eggs and Ham")_ , at number 4, _[The Cat
in the Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat "The Cat in the Hat")_ , at number 9, and
_One Fish, Two Fish, Red Fish, Blue Fish_ , at number 13.[89] In the years
after his death in 1991, two additional books were published based on his
sketches and notes: _[Hooray for Diffendoofer
Day!](/wiki/Hooray_for_Diffendoofer_Day! "Hooray for Diffendoofer Day!")_ and
_[Daisy-Head Mayzie](/wiki/Daisy-Head_Mayzie "Daisy-Head Mayzie")_. _[My Many
Colored Days](/wiki/My_Many_Colored_Days "My Many Colored Days")_ was
originally written in 1973 but was posthumously published in 1996. In
September 2011, seven stories originally published in magazines during the
1950s were released in a collection titled _[The Bippolo Seed and Other Lost
Stories](/wiki/The_Bippolo_Seed_and_Other_Lost_Stories "The Bippolo Seed and
Other Lost Stories")_.[90]

Geisel also wrote a pair of books for adults: _[The Seven Lady
Godivas](/wiki/The_Seven_Lady_Godivas "The Seven Lady Godivas")_ (1939;
reprinted 1987), a retelling of the [Lady Godiva](/wiki/Lady_Godiva "Lady
Godiva") legend that included nude depictions; and _[You're Only Old
Once!](/wiki/You%27re_Only_Old_Once! "You're Only Old Once!")_ (written in
1986 when Geisel was 82), which chronicles an [old man](/wiki/Old_age "Old
age")'s journey through a clinic. His last book was _[Oh, the Places You'll
Go!](/wiki/Oh,_the_Places_You%27ll_Go! "Oh, the Places You'll Go!")_, which
published the year before his death and became a popular gift for graduating
students.[91]

## Adaptations

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Seuss_Landing.jpg/220px-
Seuss_Landing.jpg)](/wiki/File:Seuss_Landing.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Seuss_Landing.jpg "Enlarge")

[Seuss Landing](/wiki/Universal%27s_Islands_of_Adventure#Seuss_Landing
"Universal's Islands of Adventure") at [Islands of
Adventure](/wiki/Universal%27s_Islands_of_Adventure "Universal's Islands of
Adventure") in [Orlando, Florida](/wiki/Orlando,_Florida "Orlando, Florida")

For most of his career, Geisel was reluctant to have his characters marketed
in contexts outside of his own books. However, he did permit the creation of
several animated cartoons, an art form in which he had gained experience
during World War II, and he gradually relaxed his policy as he aged.

The first adaptation of one of Geisel's works was a cartoon version of
_[Horton Hatches the Egg](/wiki/Horton_Hatches_the_Egg "Horton Hatches the
Egg")_ , animated at [Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros.") in 1942
and directed by [Bob Clampett](/wiki/Bob_Clampett "Bob Clampett"). It was
presented as part of the [Merrie Melodies](/wiki/Merrie_Melodies "Merrie
Melodies") series and included a number of gags not present in the original
narrative, including a fish committing suicide and a [Katharine
Hepburn](/wiki/Katharine_Hepburn "Katharine Hepburn") imitation by Mayzie.

As part of the Puppetoon theatrical cartoon series for [Paramount
Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures"), two of Geisel's
works were adapted into stop-motion films by George Pal. The first, "[The 500
Hats of Bartholomew Cubbins](/wiki/The_500_Hats_of_Bartholomew_Cubbins "The
500 Hats of Bartholomew Cubbins")", was released in 1943[92] and nominated for
an Academy Award for "Short Subject (Cartoon)" the following year.[93] The
second, "[And to Think I Saw It On Mulberry
Street](/wiki/And_to_Think_That_I_Saw_It_on_Mulberry_Street#film "And to Think
That I Saw It on Mulberry Street")", with a title slightly altered from [the
book's](/wiki/And_to_Think_That_I_Saw_It_on_Mulberry_Street "And to Think That
I Saw It on Mulberry Street"), was released in 1944.[94]

In 1959, Geisel authorized [Revell](/wiki/Revell "Revell"), the well-known
plastic model-making company, to make a series of "animals" that snapped
together rather than being glued together, and could be assembled,
disassembled, and re-assembled "in thousands" of ways. The series was called
the "Dr. Seuss Zoo" and included Gowdy the Dowdy Grackle, Norval the Bashful
Blinket, Tingo the Noodle Topped Stroodle, and Roscoe the Many Footed Lion.
The basic body parts were the same and all were interchangeable, and so it was
possible for children to combine parts from various characters in essentially
unlimited ways in creating their own animal characters (Revell encouraged this
by selling Gowdy, Norval, and Tingo together in a "Gift Set" as well as
individually). Revell also made a conventional glue-together "beginner's kit"
of The Cat in the Hat.

In 1966, Geisel authorized eminent cartoon artist [Chuck
Jones](/wiki/Chuck_Jones "Chuck Jones") — his friend and former colleague from
the war — to make a cartoon version of _[How the Grinch Stole
Christmas!](/wiki/How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas!_\(TV_special\) "How the
Grinch Stole Christmas! \(TV special\)")_ Geisel was credited as a co-producer
under his real name Ted Geisel, along with Jones. The cartoon was narrated by
[Boris Karloff](/wiki/Boris_Karloff "Boris Karloff"), who also provided the
voice of the Grinch. It was very faithful to the original book, and is
considered a classic to this day by many. It is often broadcast as an annual
[Christmas television special](/wiki/Christmas_television_special "Christmas
television special"). Jones directed an adaptation of _[Horton Hears a
Who!](/wiki/Horton_Hears_a_Who!_\(TV_special\) "Horton Hears a Who! \(TV
special\)")_ in 1970 and produced an adaptation of _[The Cat in the
Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(TV_special\) "The Cat in the Hat \(TV
special\)")_ in 1971.

From 1972 to 1983, Geisel wrote six animated specials that were produced by
[DePatie-Freleng](/wiki/DePatie-Freleng "DePatie-Freleng"): _[The
Lorax](/wiki/The_Lorax_\(TV_special\) "The Lorax \(TV special\)")_ (1972);
_[Dr. Seuss on the Loose](/wiki/Dr._Seuss_on_the_Loose "Dr. Seuss on the
Loose")_ (1973); _[The Hoober-Bloob Highway](/wiki/The_Hoober-Bloob_Highway
"The Hoober-Bloob Highway")_ (1975); _[Halloween Is Grinch
Night](/wiki/Halloween_Is_Grinch_Night "Halloween Is Grinch Night")_ (1977);
_[Pontoffel Pock, Where Are You?](/wiki/Pontoffel_Pock,_Where_Are_You%3F
"Pontoffel Pock, Where Are You?")_ (1980); and _[The Grinch Grinches the Cat
in the Hat](/wiki/The_Grinch_Grinches_the_Cat_in_the_Hat "The Grinch Grinches
the Cat in the Hat")_ (1982). Several of the specials won multiple
[Emmy](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award") Awards.

A [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") [paint-on-glass-
animated](/wiki/Paint-on-glass_animation "Paint-on-glass animation") short
film was made in 1986 called _[Welcome](/wiki/Welcome_\(1986_film\) "Welcome
\(1986 film\)")_ , an adaptation of _Thidwick the Big-Hearted Moose_. The last
adaptation of Geisel's work before he died was _[The Butter Battle
Book](/wiki/The_Butter_Battle_Book "The Butter Battle Book")_ , a television
special based on the book of the same name, directed by adult animation legend
[Ralph Bakshi](/wiki/Ralph_Bakshi "Ralph Bakshi").

A television film titled _[In Search of Dr.
Seuss](/wiki/In_Search_of_Dr._Seuss "In Search of Dr. Seuss")_ was released in
1994, which adapted many of Seuss's stories. It uses both live-action versions
and animated versions of the characters and stories featured; however, the
animated portions were merely edited versions of previous animated television
specials and, in some cases, re-dubbed as well.

After Geisel died of cancer at the age of 87 in 1991, his widow Audrey Geisel
was placed in charge of all licensing matters. She approved a live-action
feature-film version of _[How the Grinch Stole
Christmas](/wiki/Dr._Seuss%27_How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas_\(2000_film\)
"Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas \(2000 film\)")_ starring [Jim
Carrey](/wiki/Jim_Carrey "Jim Carrey"), as well as a Seuss-themed [Broadway
musical](/wiki/Broadway_theater "Broadway theater") called
_[Seussical](/wiki/Seussical "Seussical")_ , and both premiered in 2000. _The
Grinch_ has had limited engagement runs on Broadway during the Christmas
season, after premiering in 1998 (under the title _How the Grinch Stole
Christmas_) at the [Old Globe Theatre](/wiki/Old_Globe_Theatre "Old Globe
Theatre") in San Diego, where it has become a Christmas tradition. In 2003,
another live-action film was released, this time an adaptation of _[The Cat in
the Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\) "The Cat in the Hat \(film\)")_
that featured [Mike Myers](/wiki/Mike_Myers_\(actor\) "Mike Myers \(actor\)")
as the title character. Audrey Geisel has spoken critically of the film,
especially the casting of Myers as the Cat in the Hat, and stated that she
would not allow any further live-action adaptations of Geisel's books.[95]
However, a first animated [CGI](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery "Computer-
generated imagery") feature film adaptation of _[Horton Hears a
Who!](/wiki/Horton_Hears_a_Who!_\(film\) "Horton Hears a Who! \(film\)")_ was
approved, and was eventually released on March 14, 2008, to critical acclaim.
A second CGI-animated feature film adaptation of _[The
Lorax](/wiki/The_Lorax_\(film\) "The Lorax \(film\)")_ was released by
[Universal](/wiki/Universal_Studios "Universal Studios") on March 2, 2012 (on
what would have been Seuss's 108th birthday), and third CGI-animated feature
film adaptation of _[The Grinch](/wiki/The_Grinch_\(film\) "The Grinch
\(film\)")_ was released by [Universal](/wiki/Universal_Studios "Universal
Studios") on November 9, 2018.

Four television series have been adapted from Geisel's work. The first,
_Gerald McBoing-Boing_ , was an animated television adaptation of Geisel's
1951 cartoon [of the same name](/wiki/Gerald_McBoing-Boing "Gerald McBoing-
Boing") and lasted three months between 1956 and 1957. The second, _[The
Wubbulous World of Dr. Seuss](/wiki/The_Wubbulous_World_of_Dr._Seuss "The
Wubbulous World of Dr. Seuss")_ , was a mix of live-action and puppetry by
[Jim Henson Television](/wiki/Jim_Henson_Television "Jim Henson Television"),
the producers of [The Muppets](/wiki/The_Muppets "The Muppets"). It aired for
one season on [Nickelodeon](/wiki/Nickelodeon "Nickelodeon") in the United
States, from 1996 to 1997. The third, _[Gerald McBoing-
Boing](/wiki/Gerald_McBoing-Boing_\(TV_series\) "Gerald McBoing-Boing \(TV
series\)")_ , is a remake of the 1956 series.[96] Produced in Canada by
[Cookie Jar Entertainment](/wiki/Cookie_Jar_Entertainment "Cookie Jar
Entertainment") (now [DHX Media](/wiki/DHX_Media "DHX Media")) and North
America by [Classic Media](/wiki/Classic_Media "Classic Media") (now
[DreamWorks Classics](/wiki/DreamWorks_Classics "DreamWorks Classics")), it
ran from 2005 to 2007. The fourth, _[The Cat in the Hat Knows a Lot About
That!](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat_Knows_a_Lot_About_That! "The Cat in the Hat
Knows a Lot About That!")_ , produced by Portfolio Entertainment Inc., began
on August 7, 2010, in Canada and September 6, 2010, in the United States and
is currently still
showing.[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_]

Geisel's books and characters are also featured in [Seuss
Landing](/wiki/Seuss_Landing "Seuss Landing"), one of many islands at the
[Islands of Adventure](/wiki/Islands_of_Adventure "Islands of Adventure")
[theme park](/wiki/Theme_park "Theme park") in [Orlando,
Florida](/wiki/Orlando,_Florida "Orlando, Florida"). In an attempt to match
Geisel's visual style, there are reportedly "no straight lines" in Seuss
Landing.[97]

_[The Hollywood Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood
Reporter")_ has reported that [Warner Animation
Group](/wiki/Warner_Animation_Group "Warner Animation Group") and Dr. Seuss
Enterprises have struck a deal to make new animated movies based on the
stories of Dr. Seuss. Their first project will be a fully animated version of
[The Cat in the Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat "The Cat in the Hat").[98]
